elements.content: The first example of a new Hg2+-sensing system based on the structures of complexes is reported. The system uses a combination of a new chiral bidentate ligand and CD spectroscopy. Significant CD spectral changes are observed when Hg2+ is added, whereas no CD spectral changes are observed in the cases of Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Rb+, Ag+, Cd2+, La3+, Gd3+, and Pb2+.
elements.clean_text: The first example of a new Hg2+-sensing system based on the structures of complexes is reported. The system uses a combination of a new chiral bidentate ligand and CD spectroscopy. Significant CD spectral changes are observed when Hg2+ is added, whereas no CD spectral changes are observed in the cases of Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Rb+, Ag+, Cd2+, La3+, Gd3+, and Pb2+.

elements.content: It is well-known that Hg2+ is a highly toxic metal ion with respect to human health and the environment. Many Hg2+-ion-sensor molecules have been reported in the past decade. In general, sensor molecules for metal ions consist of three parts: a receptor, an active unit, and a spacer. Since the selectivity of a ligand depends on the receptor, the receptor is the most important of these three parts. To develop highly selective ion-sensor molecules, we need to take factors such as the ion diameters, valence electrons, electronic configurations, and coordination modes of metal ions into consideration in the design and preparation of ligands. Much effort has been put into preparing highly designed sensor molecules.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that Hg2+ is a highly toxic metal ion with respect to human health and the environment. Many Hg2+-ion-sensor molecules have been reported in the past decade. In general, sensor molecules for metal ions consist of three parts: a receptor, an active unit, and a spacer. Since the selectivity of a ligand depends on the receptor, the receptor is the most important of these three parts. To develop highly selective ion-sensor molecules, we need to take factors such as the ion diameters, valence electrons, electronic configurations, and coordination modes of metal ions into consideration in the design and preparation of ligands. Much effort has been put into preparing highly designed sensor molecules.

elements.content: However, there is another way to develop ion-selective sensor molecules. A new way is to develop a ligand that only outputs information on the specific structure of a complex between a ligand and a specific metal ion. In this case, the ligand itself does not require metal-ion selectivity. If we could develop a ligand which forms a specific structure by binding to a specific metal ion, even if the ligand does not have metal-ion selectivity, this would be a new ion-sensing system. Fluorescence and UV–vis spectroscopies have been used in many ion-sensing systems. These spectroscopies do not give information on the structures of the complexes, although they give electronic information on the ligand and/or complexes.
elements.clean_text: However, there is another way to develop ion-selective sensor molecules. A new way is to develop a ligand that only outputs information on the specific structure of a complex between a ligand and a specific metal ion. In this case, the ligand itself does not require metal-ion selectivity. If we could develop a ligand which forms a specific structure by binding to a specific metal ion, even if the ligand does not have metal-ion selectivity, this would be a new ion-sensing system. Fluorescence and UV-vis spectroscopies have been used in many ion-sensing systems. These spectroscopies do not give information on the structures of the complexes, although they give electronic information on the ligand and/or complexes.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Synthesis of (<italic toggle="yes">R</italic>)-(−)-<bold>1a</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ol-2012-002943_0007.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

CD spectroscopy is a powerful tool for determining the absolute configurations of chiral molecules and complexes on a microgram scale. The CD exciton chirality method provides valuable information on the spatial arrangement of the chromophores. When two or more chromophores situated near each other are regularly arranged spatially, the CD spectrum changes drastically, not only in intensity but also with respect to spectral shape. In addition, no CD spectral changes are observed in the case of random arrangements of the chromophores.
elements.clean_text: CD spectroscopy is a powerful tool for determining the absolute configurations of chiral molecules and complexes on a microgram scale. The CD exciton chirality method provides valuable information on the spatial arrangement of the chromophores. When two or more chromophores situated near each other are regularly arranged spatially, the CD spectrum changes drastically, not only in intensity but also with respect to spectral shape. In addition, no CD spectral changes are observed in the case of random arrangements of the chromophores.

elements.content: Metal-ion-induced CD ([metal salts] = [(R)-(−)-1] = 2.0 × 10–4 M) (a) and UV–vis spectral changes ([metal salts] = [(R)-(−)-1] = 1.9 × 10–5 M in methanol) (b).
elements.clean_text: 1  Metal-ion-induced CD ([metal salts] = [(R)-(-)-1] = 2.0 × 10-4 M) (a) and UV-vis spectral changes ([metal salts] = [(R)-(-)-1] = 1.9 × 10-5 M in methanol) (b).

elements.content: When CD spectroscopy is used to detect metal complexation, it is therefore expected that drastic CD spectral changes will be observed only for specific metal-ion arrangements. Here, we report a Hg2+-ion-sensing system based on the structures of complexes; the system uses a combination of CD spectroscopy and a new chiral bidentate ligand.
elements.clean_text: When CD spectroscopy is used to detect metal complexation, it is therefore expected that drastic CD spectral changes will be observed only for specific metal-ion arrangements. Here, we report a Hg2+-ion-sensing system based on the structures of complexes; the system uses a combination of CD spectroscopy and a new chiral bidentate ligand.

elements.content: A new chiral bidentate ligand with a 1-(1-naphthyl) group, (R)-(−)-1 (Scheme ), was prepared in 75% yield by the reductive amination of (R)-(+)-1-(1-naphthyl)ethylamine with 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde in the presence of NaBH(OAc)3. We have also prepared some analogs bearing 1-(2-naphthyl), 1-phenyl, and 1-cyclohexyl groups as a chiral moiety and 3-pyridyl groups as binding sites (see the compound list in the ). However, only (R)-(−)-1 showed a significant CD spectral change on addition of Hg2+ ions.
elements.clean_text: A new chiral bidentate ligand with a 1-(1-naphthyl) group, (R)-(-)-1 (Scheme ), was prepared in 75% yield by the reductive amination of (R)-(+)-1-(1-naphthyl)ethylamine with 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde in the presence of NaBH(OAc)3. We have also prepared some analogs bearing 1-(2-naphthyl), 1-phenyl, and 1-cyclohexyl groups as a chiral moiety and 3-pyridyl groups as binding sites (see the compound list in the ). However, only (R)-(-)-1 showed a significant CD spectral change on addition of Hg2+ ions.

elements.content: The complexing properties of (R)-(−)-1 toward several metal ions were examined, based on metal-ion-induced CD and UV–vis spectral changes in methanol (Figure a and b). In the CD spectra (Figure a), free (R)-(−)-1 exhibits a negative Cotton effect at λext 225 nm. When equimolar amounts of Hg2+ were added, drastic spectral changes were observed at λext 225 and 214 nm, whereas no CD spectral changes were observed upon addition of equimolar amounts of Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Rb+, Ag+, Cd2+, La3+, Gd3+, and Pb2+ ions. On the other hand, a slight UV–vis spectral change was observed on addition of Hg2+ ions (Figure b), although no spectral changes were observed on addition of the other metal ions. These results indicate that a sensing system using CD spectroscopy with (R)-(−)-1 provides complete Hg2+ selectivity.
elements.clean_text: The complexing properties of (R)-(-)-1 toward several metal ions were examined, based on metal-ion-induced CD and UV-vis spectral changes in methanol (Figure a and b). In the CD spectra (Figure a), free (R)-(-)-1 exhibits a negative Cotton effect at λext 225 nm. When equimolar amounts of Hg2+ were added, drastic spectral changes were observed at λext 225 and 214 nm, whereas no CD spectral changes were observed upon addition of equimolar amounts of Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Rb+, Ag+, Cd2+, La3+, Gd3+, and Pb2+ ions. On the other hand, a slight UV-vis spectral change was observed on addition of Hg2+ ions (Figure b), although no spectral changes were observed on addition of the other metal ions. These results indicate that a sensing system using CD spectroscopy with (R)-(-)-1 provides complete Hg2+ selectivity.

elements.content: To clarify the reasons for this selectivity toward Hg2+ ions by (R)-(−)-1, the structure of the (R)-(−)-1–Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex was confirmed by cold ESI-MS and 1H NMR spectroscopy. Cold ESI-MS is an excellent tool for confirming the presence of unstable species and/or species with large molecular weights, and the data reflect the structures in solution (Figure ). The cold ESI-MS of a 1:1 mixture of (R)-(−)-1 and Hg(CF3SO3)2 was measured in methanol.
elements.clean_text: To clarify the reasons for this selectivity toward Hg2+ ions by (R)-(-)-1, the structure of the (R)-(-)-1-Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex was confirmed by cold ESI-MS and 1H NMR spectroscopy. Cold ESI-MS is an excellent tool for confirming the presence of unstable species and/or species with large molecular weights, and the data reflect the structures in solution (Figure ). The cold ESI-MS of a 1:1 mixture of (R)-(-)-1 and Hg(CF3SO3)2 was measured in methanol.

elements.content: Cold ESI-MS of a mixture of (R)-(−)-1 and Hg(CF3SO3)2 (1:1) in methanol (298 K).
elements.clean_text: 2  Cold ESI-MS of a mixture of (R)-(-)-1 and Hg(CF3SO3)2 (1:1) in methanol (298 K).

elements.content: The fragment ion peaks arising from [(R)-(−)-1 + Hg2+ – H+]+, [2(R)-(−)-1 + 2Hg2+ + 2OTf–]2+, [2(R)-(−)-1 + 2Hg2+ + 3OTf–]+, [4(R)-(−)-1 + 4Hg2+ + 7OTf–]+, and [6(R)-(−)-1 + 6Hg2+ + 10OTf–]2+ were observed at m/z = 554, 703, 1555, 3259, and 2408, respectively. The patterns of the fragment ion peaks agree with the theoretical distributions (see Figure S1d and S1e in the ). The mass data suggest that the Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex with (R)-(−)-1 is a (1:1) n coordination polymer. 1H NMR titration experiments were carried out in methanol-d 4 (see Figure S1f in the ). The naphthalene protons in the complex were assigned using 1H–1H COSY and 1D 1H NOE difference spectroscopies (see Figure S1g and S1h in the ). When equimolar amounts of Hg(CF3SO3)2 were added, (i) the signal widths of the pyridine protons broadened and (ii) the signals of the 8-position proton of the naphthalene and the methine proton of the chiral center shifted to lower field by about 0.7 ppm. These results suggest that the complex is a coordination polymer, and the naphthalene and methine protons are located in a deshielding area of the pyridine rings.
elements.clean_text: The fragment ion peaks arising from [(R)-(-)-1 + Hg2+ - H+]+, [2(R)-(-)-1 + 2Hg2+ + 2OTf-]2+, [2(R)-(-)-1 + 2Hg2+ + 3OTf-]+, [4(R)-(-)-1 + 4Hg2+ + 7OTf-]+, and [6(R)-(-)-1 + 6Hg2+ + 10OTf-]2+ were observed at m/z = 554, 703, 1555, 3259, and 2408, respectively. The patterns of the fragment ion peaks agree with the theoretical distributions (see Figure S1d and S1e in the ). The mass data suggest that the Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex with (R)-(-)-1 is a (1:1) n  coordination polymer. 1H NMR titration experiments were carried out in methanol-d 4 (see Figure S1f in the ). The naphthalene protons in the complex were assigned using 1H-1H COSY and 1D 1H NOE difference spectroscopies (see Figure S1g and S1h in the ). When equimolar amounts of Hg(CF3SO3)2 were added, (i) the signal widths of the pyridine protons broadened and (ii) the signals of the 8-position proton of the naphthalene and the methine proton of the chiral center shifted to lower field by about 0.7 ppm. These results suggest that the complex is a coordination polymer, and the naphthalene and methine protons are located in a deshielding area of the pyridine rings.

elements.content: Hg2+-induced CD ([Hg(CF3SO3)2] = [(R)-(−)-1] = 2.0 × 10–4 M (a) and UV–vis spectral changes ([Hg(CF3SO3)2] = [(R)-(−)-1] = 2.0 × 10–5 M in methanol) (b).
elements.clean_text: 3  Hg2+-induced CD ([Hg(CF3SO3)2] = [(R)-(-)-1] = 2.0 × 10-4 M (a) and UV-vis spectral changes ([Hg(CF3SO3)2] = [(R)-(-)-1] = 2.0 × 10-5 M in methanol) (b).

elements.content: To obtain stereochemical information on the Hg2+ complex, titration experiments using UV–vis and CD spectroscopies were carried out (Figure a and b). These titration experiments indicate the following: (i) the absorbance at the λmax arising from the 1Bb transition of the naphthalene unit increases about 1.05 times with the addition of Hg(CF3SO3)2 (Figure b); (ii) the first (λext 225 nm) and second (λext 214 nm) Cotton effects in the CD spectra appear in the region of the 1Bb transition, and small CD spectral changes are observed around λext 270 nm, arising from the pyridines (Figure a). These results clearly suggest that the CD spectral pattern shows exciton coupling between the naphthalene units. It is well-known that a pair of first negative and second positive Cotton effects indicates the counterclockwise screw sense between two or more axe; therefore the arrangement between the naphthalene units in the (R)-(−)-1–Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex would be the counterclockwise screw sense. In addition, plotting the absorbance at 250 nm vs [Hg(CF3SO3)2]/[(R)-(−)-1] ratios showed a sigmoidal curve which fits a logistic function (see Figure S1i, S1j, and S1k in the ). The sigmoidal curve indicates that the binding of (R)-(−)-1 to Hg(CF3SO3)2 is autoaccelerative. It is well-known that the cooperative guest binding profile can be analyzed with the Hill equation, log[y/(1 – y)] = n log[guest] + log K, where n and K are the Hill coefficient and overall association constant between the ligand and Hg2+, respectively. From the slope and intercept of the linear plot, we obtained n = 2.09 and log K = 10.8 (correlation coefficient R 2 = 0.97). The n value is nearly 2, meaning that two binding sites of (R)-(−)-1 work cooperatively.
elements.clean_text: To obtain stereochemical information on the Hg2+ complex, titration experiments using UV-vis and CD spectroscopies were carried out (Figure a and b). These titration experiments indicate the following: (i) the absorbance at the λmax arising from the 1Bb transition of the naphthalene unit increases about 1.05 times with the addition of Hg(CF3SO3)2 (Figure b); (ii) the first (λext 225 nm) and second (λext 214 nm) Cotton effects in the CD spectra appear in the region of the 1Bb transition, and small CD spectral changes are observed around λext 270 nm, arising from the pyridines (Figure a). These results clearly suggest that the CD spectral pattern shows exciton coupling between the naphthalene units. It is well-known that a pair of first negative and second positive Cotton effects indicates the counterclockwise screw sense between two or more axe; therefore the arrangement between the naphthalene units in the (R)-(-)-1-Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex would be the counterclockwise screw sense. In addition, plotting the absorbance at 250 nm vs [Hg(CF3SO3)2]/[(R)-(-)-1] ratios showed a sigmoidal curve which fits a logistic function (see Figure S1i, S1j, and S1k in the ). The sigmoidal curve indicates that the binding of (R)-(-)-1 to Hg(CF3SO3)2 is autoaccelerative. It is well-known that the cooperative guest binding profile can be analyzed with the Hill equation, log[y/(1 - y)] = n log[guest] + log K, where n and K are the Hill coefficient and overall association constant between the ligand and Hg2+, respectively. From the slope and intercept of the linear plot, we obtained n = 2.09 and log K = 10.8 (correlation coefficient R 2 = 0.97). The n value is nearly 2, meaning that two binding sites of (R)-(-)-1 work cooperatively.

elements.content: Partial X-ray crystal structure of the Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex. Front view (a) and side view (b).
elements.clean_text: 4  Partial X-ray crystal structure of the Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex. Front view (a) and side view (b).

elements.content: (R)-(−)-1 in chloroform was treated with equimolar amounts of Hg(CF3SO3)2 in methanol to give the (R)-(−)-1-Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex in quantitative yield. The structure of the Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex with (R)-(−)-1 was determined by X-ray crystallography. Figure shows tube and line diagrams of the complex (Figure S11 shows selected distances and angles). The complex is a zigzag polymer-like complex. The Hg2+ ion is six-coordinated by the pyridine N2 and N3 atoms, and the O1, O3, O4, and O5 atoms of the CF3SO3 anions. Interestingly, opposite CF3SO3 anions bridge two Hg2+ ions to form a looped one-dimensional network structure. It is important to note that the bidentate double-bridging anions play a crucial role as a backbone in the assembly of this unique and robust supramolecular network. The 8-position hydrogen in the naphthalene (colored red in Figure S11) and the methine hydrogen are located in the deshielding area of two pyridines. The X-ray structure therefore supports the predictions of a polymer-like structure made on the basis of the cold ESI-MS and the chemical shift changes in the 1H NMR titration experiments. We have tried to make other metal complexes with (R)-(−)-1, but no crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained. The naphthalene units in the solid state are arranged in an eclipsed form, which should not give exciton coupling in the CD spectrum. This result could be caused by a packing effect in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: (R)-(-)-1 in chloroform was treated with equimolar amounts of Hg(CF3SO3)2 in methanol to give the (R)-(-)-1-Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex in quantitative yield. The structure of the Hg(CF3SO3)2 complex with (R)-(-)-1 was determined by X-ray crystallography. Figure  shows tube and line diagrams of the complex (Figure S11 shows selected distances and angles). The complex is a zigzag polymer-like complex. The Hg2+ ion is six-coordinated by the pyridine N2 and N3 atoms, and the O1, O3, O4, and O5 atoms of the CF3SO3 anions. Interestingly, opposite CF3SO3 anions bridge two Hg2+ ions to form a looped one-dimensional network structure. It is important to note that the bidentate double-bridging anions play a crucial role as a backbone in the assembly of this unique and robust supramolecular network. The 8-position hydrogen in the naphthalene (colored red in Figure S11) and the methine hydrogen are located in the deshielding area of two pyridines. The X-ray structure therefore supports the predictions of a polymer-like structure made on the basis of the cold ESI-MS and the chemical shift changes in the 1H NMR titration experiments. We have tried to make other metal complexes with (R)-(-)-1, but no crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained. The naphthalene units in the solid state are arranged in an eclipsed form, which should not give exciton coupling in the CD spectrum. This result could be caused by a packing effect in the solid state.

elements.content: In summary, we demonstrated a Hg2+-ion-sensing system based on the structures of complexes, using CD spectroscopy and a chiral bidentate ligand. The Hg2+-specific CD spectral changes are the result of exciton coupling between the naphthalene units of the chiral coordination polymer. This system provides a route to new sensing systems using chiral ligands and CD spectroscopy. Investigations of the effects of counteranions of Hg2+ on the CD and UV–vis spectral changes are now in progress.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we demonstrated a Hg2+-ion-sensing system based on the structures of complexes, using CD spectroscopy and a chiral bidentate ligand. The Hg2+-specific CD spectral changes are the result of exciton coupling between the naphthalene units of the chiral coordination polymer. This system provides a route to new sensing systems using chiral ligands and CD spectroscopy. Investigations of the effects of counteranions of Hg2+ on the CD and UV-vis spectral changes are now in progress.

metadata.title: Hg2+-Sensing System Based on Structures of Complexes
